"Maria Gobbett has been living with me several times for two years and ten months; she left me in May, 1848, went to Gravesend, and was committed for a month; her brother gave me this clock to sell, as he had a distress in his house, and I sold it for him to Mrs. Manning; I was taken into custody in May twelvemonth, and had twelve months imprisonment; during my imprisonment, Maria Gobbett got aquainted with a policeman, who made her drunk, and gave her a sum of money to tell what she knew about certain robberies committed by me; so I was taken into custody for this clock; the policeman has been in the habit of sleeping with her at a house of ill-fame; she has done this because I would not live with her any longer."

MARIA GOBBETT
re-examined. It is all false.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1692.
JOHN MALONEY
, stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; the goods of
William Henry Draper: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Four Months.

1693.
FREDERICK JAMES TARRANT
, stealing 3 handkerchiefs, value 7s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Poile, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

1694.
WILLIAM JACOBS
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Poile, his master.

THOMAS POILE . I am a pawnbroker. On 28th June I had a conversation with Tarrant, who has pleaded guilty—while I was in conversation with him the prisoner Jacobs came in—I imagine he had heard what had passed between me and Tarrant.
MR. PARRY. Q. What you said to Jacobs do you think Tarrant had

heard? A. I should think he must—I said to Tarrant, "Where did you get this handkerchief? tell me, or I will send for a constable"—in the early part of that Saturday morning I had found several wrappers, and suspected a robbery—I had not seen Jacobs then when I spoke to Tarrant.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What did Tarrant say upon that observation of yours, and before you saw that Jacobs was in sight? A. He said, "I have robbed you of that handkerchief, Sir"—(that was another handkerchief)—and then he said, "Jacobs has robbed you as much as I have"—Jacobs then came from a back warehouse, and said, "You know you are a liar; I have not; I have only robbed you of one silk-handkerchief; "and he took a key from his pocket, and took the handkerchief from his box in the presence of my son, who came up-stairs at that moment.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Had you asked him any question about Jacobs before? A. No—after he told me he had robbed me of this handkerchief, and he had said this of Jacobs, he called to Jacobs and said, "Come forward, you have robbed master as well as Í have;" Jacobs said, "You are a liar; I have only taken one handkerchief."

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1695.
RICHARD COE
, stealing 1lbs. 5ozs. weight of leather, value 1s.; the goods of
William Myall; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year ,

1696.
JAMES MORTON
, stealing 1 coat, value 15s.; the goods of
Robert Samuel Boulter; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

1697.
ALFRED HAYNES
, stealing-15 shirts, value 15s. 6d.; the goods of
James Browning; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year.

1698.
HENRY JAGGERS
, stealing 10 sovereigns; the moneys of
Wil
liam Chapman Rawley, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

1699.
JAMES CLEAR and
PATRICK SULLIVAN
, breaking and entering the warehouse of
Richard Wills and another, and stealing 1 quart of brandy, value 2s.; their goods.

GEORGE BRIGHT . I am in the service of Richard Wills and another, of Southwark; the prisoners were in their employ. Last Wednesday evening I was in their warehouse—there were two vessels off there, loading for Devon-port—I came out about six o'clock, and shut the door, which shuts with a spring-latch—I left everything safe—I went to another warehouse, and returned about seven—I then smelt a strong smell of spirits, and saw the warehouse-door half open—I looked in, and said, "Who is here?"—a person answered—I looked in with a short piece of candle, and saw the prisoners, and a cask was running from two holes—I knew it was spirits, and said to Clear," For God's sake, James, what are you doing? don't let the spirits run away; put your fingers on the holes, while I get another candle"—I went to get another candle, and saw Dyton—we returned to the cellar, and there was no one there.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Whose property was this? A. The spirits are supposed to be the property of the wharfingers.

JOHN DYTON . I am in the employ of Mr. Richard Wills and another. I was called to this warehouse about seven o'clock that evening—I found the brandy running out of two holes in the cask, made I suppose with a gimlet—there was a cooper's adze and some bottles close by; one of them had brandy in it—Clear works there, and Sullivan occasionally—they had no business there at that time.

CLEAR—
GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

SULLIVAN—
GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1700.
CHARLES EDWARDS
, stealing 1 screw-wrench, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Esau Dodge: having been before convicted.

ESAU DODGE . I live in Wellington-place, Blackfriars, On 10th Aug. the prisoner came, and spoke about buying a horse—he left some time after, and I missed a screw-wrench—I sent my servant after him—he refused to return—I have no doubt that he is the person.

NATHAN HAYWARD . I am in the prosecutor's service. On 10th Aug., about ten minutes before four o'clock, the prisoner came—I was up in the loft—I saw him go to the cab, and take out a screw-wrench which I had put there—he called out for Mr. George, and asked him if he wanted to buy a horse—I saw him go away with the wrench.
Prisoner. Q. How was I dressed? A. You had a light drab coat and a cap on.
Prisoner. I had a hat on from three o'clock till five that day; I was at the Tom Thumb, in the New-cut; there was a sale there.

JAMES CUDDY (policeman, L 194). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted Feb., 1847, and confined nine months)—he is the person—I have had him in custody since then, for threatening the life of his mother, and he had three months.

GUILTY .†—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 17TH
